metadata.title: Bipolar carbide-carbon high voltage aqueous lithium-ion capacitors

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoen
Full paper
Bipolar carbide-carbon high voltage aqueous lithium-ion capacitors
Jianmin Lia,b, Narendra Kurraa, Mykola Seredycha, Xing Menga,c, Hongzhi Wangb, Yury Gogotsia,c,⁎
a A.J. Drexel Nanomaterials Institute and Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA b State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Donghua University, Shanghai 201620, PR China c Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries (Ministry of Education), College of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: MXene Carbide-derived carbon Asymmetric Energy storage Bipolar
A B S T R A C T
MXenes - two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and nitrides - are an emerging class of high rate pseudocapacitive materials due to their combination of fast surface redox reactions with metallic conductivity. The ability of MXenes to spontaneously intercalate aqueous cations, broadens the scope for developing metal-ion capacitors beyond the protic electrolytes. In this study, 2D titanium carbide (MXene) free-standing films are employed to evaluate the dependence of electrochemical performance in aqueous Li and Na-ion electrolytes. By contrast, high surface area porous nanoscale carbide derived carbon (nano-CDC) is employed as a surface electrosorbing electrode at anodic potentials. Both, 2D MXene and zero-dimensional (0D) nano-CDC, with contrasting charge storage mechanisms and complementary potential windows of operation, enable the construction of an aqueous Li-ion capacitor with a 2 V voltage window of operation. This asymmetric device shows high rate capability (71% retention from 10 to 1000mV s−1) and good cycling stability with 99.3% retention after 10,000 cycles. Furthermore, we demonstrate here the design of flexible bipolar carbide-carbon devices.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
There is an increasing demand for developing electrochemical energy storage devices [1–4]. Batteries involve reversible redox reactions through metal ion insertion/extraction into/out of electrode materials, giving rise to high energy density at the expense of low power density due to the sluggish insertion kinetics of metal ions [2,5–7]. While electrochemical capacitors (ECs) rely on surface charge adsorption/ desorption mechanism for charge storage instead of intercalation, exhibiting high power capabilities and fast charge-discharge rates at low energy densities. Ironically, the trade-off between energy and power densities is linked to the mechanism of charge storage and the associated kinetics of electrolyte ions across electrode materials [8–10]. Pseudocapacitive energy storage combines fast surface redox reactions with capacitive (fast kinetics) characteristics, showing promise for the development of high energy and high-power systems. For instance, metal oxides and conducting polymers exhibit reversible surface redox reactions at high charge-discharge rates, delivering energy density comparable to batteries, while maintaining a power density similar to electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs) [11–14]. However, the mediocre electronic conductivity of traditional pseudocapacitive
materials is a bottleneck resulting in poor power density and limited cycling stability.
Recently, a large family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and nitrides, labelled MXenes, have shown promise for high rate pseudocapacitive energy storage due to their highly reversible surface redox reactions and metallic conductivity [15–19]. Usually, MXenes (Mn+1Xn) are synthesized by selective etching of the A group element from ternary layered ceramic materials known as MAX phases, which can be represented by the general formula Mn+1AXn, where M is an early transition metal (e.g., Ti, Nb, Mo, V, Cr, Ta), A is an element from group 13 or 14 in the periodic table (e.g., Al, Si, Ga, In), and X is carbon (C) and/or nitrogen (N), with n=1, 2, or 3 [20–23]. For instance, titanium carbide (Ti3C2Tx, Tx represents the mixed surface terminations of -O, -OH, -F) is the most studied MXene, due to its welloptimized etching and delamination protocols [24,25]. Its properties including high metallic conductivity (up to 10,000 S/cm), packing density (4 g/cm3), and redox chemistry at the metal oxide/hydroxidelike surfaces with tunable functionality, enabled Ti3C2Tx MXene to realize high-rate energy storage applications. High-rate performance and high specific volumetric capacitances (1–1.5 kF/cm3) of Ti3C2Tx MXene electrodes have been reported in acidic electrolytes [26,27].
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2018.11.042 Received 2 October 2018; Received in revised form 6 November 2018; Accepted 15 November 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: gogotsi@drexel.edu (Y. Gogotsi).
Nano Energy 56 (2019) 151–159
Available online 17 November 2018 2211-2855/ © 2018 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
T
However, symmetric titanium carbide MXene supercapacitors are limited by low operating voltage window (~ 0.6 V) in aqueous electrolytes because Ti3C2Tx is prone to oxidation at higher anodic potentials [28–30]. To expand the voltage window of operation, asymmetric device configuration was proposed where carbon or metal oxide were employed as positive electrodes [31,32]. Recently, Ti3C2Tx was paired with a ruthenium oxide (RuO2) [32] electrode to fabricate an allpseudocapacitive asymmetric device operating in a 1.5 V window. Most of the reports in the literature were focused on using acidic electrolytes, and in these cases the maximum voltage window of 1.5 V was reported. To further expand the voltage window of operation, the choice of positive electrode materials plays significant role in governing the device capacitance, rate capability and cycling stability. Nanoscale carbide derived carbon (nano-CDC) electrodes have shown great potential as they have a much higher conductivity than activated carbons and their pore size can be matched to the ion size [33]. Therefore, combining pseudocapacitive 2D MXene with a nano-CDC capacitive double-layer electrode is not only interesting in terms of achieving a wide voltage window of operation but also enabling the flexible design of bipolar devices for improved volumetric performance.
In this study, we have combined 2D Ti3C2Tx and nano-CDC electrodes in neutral aqueous Li-ion electrolyte to design a high-voltage (2 V) flexible asymmetric device. The complementary potential windows of operation of MXene and carbon with different charge storage mechanisms are the key for designing a hybrid energy storage device with excellent cycling stability. We further demonstrated the bipolar design of a Li-ion capacitor.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of delaminated Ti3C2Tx MXene
sections.text:
All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Layered ternary carbide Ti3AlC2 (MAX phase) powder was obtained from Carbon-Ukraine ltd. (particle size< 40 µm). Ti3C2Tx MXene was synthesized by following minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) route through selective etching of aluminum from Ti3AlC2 using in situ HF-forming etchant as previously as reported in very detail elsewhere [34]. The etching solution was prepared by adding 1 g lithium fluoride (LiF, Alfa Aesar, 98+ %) to 20mL of 9M hydrochloric acid (HCl, Fisher, technical grade, 35–38%), followed by stirring for 5min. 1 g of Ti3AlC2 powder was slowly added to the etchant solution at room temperature and continued stirring for 24 h at 600 rpm. The acidic suspension was washed with deionized (DI) water until pH ≥ 6 via centrifugation at 3500 rpm (5min per cycle) and decanting the clear supernatant after each cycle. Around pH ≥ 6, stable dark green supernatant of Ti3C2Tx was observed and then collected after 30min centrifugation at 3500 rpm. The concentration of Ti3C2Tx solution was measured by filtering specific amounts of colloidal solution through a polypropylene filter (3501 Coated PP, Celgard LLC, Charlotte, NC), followed by drying under vacuum at 70 °C overnight.
2.2. Preparation of freestanding Ti3C2Tx MXene film
The freestanding Ti3C2Tx MXene films were prepared by vacuum assisted filtration. These films were dried in a desiccator overnight.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of CDC electrodes
sections.text:
Nano-CDC particles were synthesized by adopting the previously reported procedure [33]. Titanium carbide (TiC) nanoparticles (20 nm diameter, MTI Crystal) were loaded into a quartz tube furnace and treated under Cl2 gas flow at 800 °C for 5 h. The resulting CDC was annealed under H2 gas at 600 °C for 2 h. Then, the as prepared nanoCDC was mixed with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) dispersion (60 wt % in water) (Sigma Aldrich), whose weight ratio was 5 wt% while nano-
CDC was 95wt%. To get a viscous slurry, the mixture was mixed in an agate mortar. Finally, the freestanding nano-CDC film was made by rolling through a press followed by drying in vacuum oven at 70 °C overnight. Typical thickness of nano-CDC film is 27 µm at a mass loading of 5mg cm−2, with a density of 1.85 g/cm3.

sections.heading: 2.4. Material characterization
sections.text: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a powder diffractometer (Rigaku Smart Lab, USA) with Cu Kα radiation at a step size of 0.04° with 0.5 s dwelling time. Raman spectra were recorded using a Renishaw Raman microscope with LEICA CTR6000 setup with 633 nm laser, 1200 lines mm−1 grating at 10% of laser power and 50X objective. Spectra were acquired with a dwell time of 120 s and accumulations of 2–4. The morphology and microstructure of the samples were characterized by a scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Zeiss Supra 50VP, Germany). The electrical conductivity of the samples was measured using a four-point probe (ResTest v1, Jandel Engineering Ltd., Bedfordshire, UK) with a probe distance of 1mm.

sections.heading: 2.5. Porosity characterization
sections.text: Specific surface area and porosity of the nano-CDC were analyzed by nitrogen adsorption at −196 °C using a Quadrasorb gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, USA). The sample was degassed at 100 mTorr and 120 °C for 12 h prior to the actual measurement. The specific surface area, SBET, was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method in the relative pressure range, p/po, from 0.05 to 0.30 [35]. The total pore volume, Vt, was calculated from the last point of the nitrogen adsorption isotherm at p/ po equal to 0.99. The pore size distribution was calculated using the manufacturer's software SAIEUS (Norcross, GA, USA) and two-dimensional nonlocal density functional theory, 2D-NLDFT [36].

sections.heading: 2.6. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The electrochemical tests (CV, GCD, and EIS) were conducted at room temperature using a VMP3 electrochemical workstation (BioLogic, France). EIS measurements were performed in the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz at an open circuit potential by applying a small sinusoidal potential signal with an amplitude of 10mV. The 3- electrode measurements were performed in 1M Li2SO4, 1M LiClO4, 1M Na2SO4 and 1M H2SO4 electrolytes, in which Ti3C2Tx and nano-CDC freestanding electrodes were employed as the working electrodes with over-capacitive activated carbon and Ag/AgCl as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively.
2.7. Fabrication of activated carbon (AC) films
Activated carbon (AC, named YP50F) films were prepared by mixing 5 wt% polytetrafluoroethylene (60 wt% in water, Sigma Aldrich) to 95 wt% of YP50F (Kuraray, Japan). The above slurry was rolled into 100 µm thick films followed by drying in a vacuum oven at 70 °C overnight. These AC films were used as over-capacitive counter electrodes for 3-electrode tests.

sections.heading: 2.8. Fabrication of asymmetric devices and bipolar devices
sections.text: The asymmetric device was assembled by using Ti3C2Tx freestanding film as a negative electrode, nano-CDC film as a positive electrode, and Celgard 3501 membrane as a separator. Aqueous 1M Li2SO4 solution was used as the electrolyte. The conductive copper tape worked as lead for both electrodes with KAPTON tape as a sealant preventing contact with the electrolyte. Also, asymmetric cells were sealed using a commercial KAPTON tape to avoid the electrolyte leakage.

sections.heading: 2.9. Calculations
sections.text:

∫=C mv idV 1 Vm (1)

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
2D titanium carbide was synthesized by selective etching of the Al layer from ternary titanium aluminum carbide (Ti3AlC2) phase, followed by delamination assisted by hydrated Li-ions, as illustrated in Fig. 1a [34]. 2D Ti3C2Tx sheets obtained in this fashion are hydrophilic and can form stable colloidal solutions in water due to negative surface charges. The ease of solution processability enabled the processing of 2D MXenes in the form of free-standing films by vacuum-assisted filtration. The cross-sectional SEM image shows the parallel arrangement of MXene flakes produced on restacking (Fig. 1b). Nano-CDC particles were synthesized from TiC nanoparticles through chlorination and hydrogenation (shown in Fig. 1c, see Experimental section for further details). Gogotsi et al. [37–41], have demonstrated a significant increase of capacitance when the pore diameter matches the size of desolvated ions. They have further studied the dependence of electrode capacitance on the CDC particle size (20 nm to hundreds of micrometers) as well as chlorination and hydrogenation temperatures. In this study, we have chosen nano-CDC as a surface adsorptive electrode to demonstrate the concept of carbide-carbon asymmetric device because small-size carbon particle allows manufacturing thin electrode film. The prepared nano-CDC powder was mixed with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) in a weight ratio of 5 wt% to produce a slurry. Finally, the freestanding nano-CDC film was fabricated by rolling through a press followed by drying in vacuum oven at 70 °C overnight, and corresponding cross-section SEM image is shown in Fig. 1d. Nano-CDC particles were glued together through polymer chains to maintain the macroscopic continuity. Moreover, both films showed highly uniform
and compact textures, with good mechanical integrity. Additionally, the high-magnification SEM image of the nano-CDC film (Fig. S1, Supplementary materials) shows a typical particle size of ~ 30 nm. In this study, we employed 2D Ti3C2Tx as a negative electrode with nanoCDC as a positive electrode to demonstrate the carbide-carbon asymmetric device.
As reported previously, the current flow in bipolar devices is in through-plane direction instead of in-plane, and this can effectively shorten the electron transport distance, lowering the resistance [42–44]. By using the shared bipolar electrode, the structure of the device can be simplified significantly, catering to the demands of practical applications. Moreover, because of the excellent electrical conductivity (~10,000 S/cm) and mechanical stability of the Ti3C2Tx film, there is no need of metal current collector to facilitate the easy construction of bipolar devices. Thus, we connected bipolar devices in series and parallel, to evaluate the potential of practical applications of carbide-carbon flexible asymmetric supercapacitor, whose schematic illustrations are shown in Fig. 1e.
As shown in Fig. 2a, Ti3C2Tx film showed only (00Ɩ) peaks, indicating the restacking of delaminated MXene sheets upon vacuum filtration. No peaks related to the parent MAX phase were observed, indicating that delaminated solution is comprised of MXene sheets only. The (002) peak was observed at 2θ=8°, corresponding to the interlayer spacing of 11.07 Å (FWHM of (002) peak is 1.6°). The presence of intercalated water may give rise to higher d-spacings which may be beneficial for the transportation of protons and metal ions in the aqueous media. The Raman spectrum of nano-CDC (Fig. 2b) shows broad D and G bands centered around 1331 and 1583 cm−1 with FWHMs of 223 and 107 cm−1, respectively. The D band arises due to defects and is related to zone boundary κ-point phonons with A1 g symmetry [45]. The G band is due to collective symmetric stretching of sp2 carbon lattice with E2 g symmetry [46,47]. The Raman spectrum shown in Fig. 2b has typical signatures of Ti3C2Tx MXene [25], matching very well with literature reports.
The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of nano-CDC and pore size distributions were calculated using two-dimensional nonlocal density functional theory (2D-NLDFT), as shown in Fig. 2c,d. Nano-CDC exhibited Type II isotherms according to the Brunauer classification [48]. The volume of N2 adsorbed significantly increases with the relative pressure suggesting that the presence of mesopores mainly between microporous nanoparticles with a mesopore volume (0.438 cm3/ g). CDC has a micro/mesoporous structure with bimodal pore size distribution and the average pore sizes of 0.8 and 2.5 nm, respectively. Specific surface area, pore volume and pore width of nano-CDC can be tuned based on the processing conditions [33]. Nano-CDC has a specific surface area of 1034m2/g with a volume of micropores ~ 0.548 cm3/g, which is significantly higher compared to Ti3C2Tx MXene (~ 98m2/g) [16]. These parameters are important for accessing the electrochemical performance of nano-CDC electrodes [49,50].
To date, Ti3C2Tx MXene has been extensively studied in acidic electrolytes, where it exhibits proton induced pseudocapacitance due to the protonation of functional groups accompanied by a change of titanium redox state. To determine the capacitance and working potential windows of 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene electrodes in Li- and Na-electrolytes, we have performed three-electrode measurements using free-standing Ti3C2Tx films as working electrodes. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves displayed in Fig. 3a provide snapshots of potential window of operation and capacitance of 2D Ti3C2Tx electrode in electrolytes including 1M Li2SO4, 1M Na2SO4 and 1M LiClO4. The maximum potential window of 1.2 V (-1.1–0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl) was observed for 1M Li2SO4 at 10mV s−1, while showing 1.1 V (-0.9–0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl) and 1 V (-0.9–0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl) for 1M Na2SO4 and 1M LiClO4 electrolytes, respectively. These differences could be based on pH values of electrolytes (pH values of 1M Li2SO4, 1M LiClO4 and 1M Na2SO4 solutions were measured to be 8.1, 6.3 and 6, respectively). Activity of protons in the electrolyte medium governs the cathodic potential operation of
Ti3C2Tx. This is in agreement with 1M H2SO4 (pH = 1.2), where the potential window of operation was found to be 1 V, as shown in Fig. S2. The shape of CV profiles and magnitude of capacitance values of Ti3C2Tx MXene electrodes are highly dependent on the cation and anion of electrolyte. To gain insights regarding the kinetics of metal cations insertion into the 2D Ti3C2Tx charge host, we performed b-value analysis for different electrolytes. The relationship between the current
response and scan rate is given by the following formula [51,52]:
=i avb (9)
where i is the current response (mA), v is the scan rate (mV s−1), a and b are two constants. For b =0.5, diffusion-controlled kinetics of ions, while for b=1, surface capacitive processes are dominant. The b values for all three electrolytes were found to be> 0.9 (10mV s−1 to
Fig. 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx and (b) cross-section SEM image of Ti3C2Tx freestanding film. (c) Synthesis scheme for nano-CDC from the parent nanoTiC, and (d) cross-section SEM image of nanoCDC film. (e) Schematic representation of the in-series and in-parallel connected bipolar device, through construction of asymmetric Liion capacitor using negative 2D Ti3C2Tx and positive nano-CDC electrodes.
1000mV s−1), indicating the pseudocapacitive behavior of Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 3b). It has been demonstrated that metal ions can be spontaneously adsorbed and intercalated on and between Ti3C2Tx sheets having negative surface charges even without applied potential [16].
The volumetric specific capacitance values of 2D Ti3C2Tx in these three electrolytes were compared in Fig. 3c. The highest volumetric capacitance of 226 F cm−3 was obtained in 1M Li2SO4 at 10mV s−1, which is higher than 209 F cm−3 for 1M LiClO4 and 187 F cm−3 for 1M Na2SO4. At a scan rate of 100mV s−1, the volumetric capacitance in 1M Li2SO4 was found to be 205 F cm−3 (retention of 91%) and it retained 73% of the initial capacitance (165 F cm−3) at a high scan rate of 1000mV s−1. Further, the rate performance was evaluated to be better in 1M Li2SO4 compared to other two electrolytes tested here. This may be due to its higher ionic conductivity and smaller size of Li+ ions compared to Na+ ions. And, its gravimetric capacitance values tested in 1M Li2SO4 is in the range of 96–73 F g−1. Previous studies showed that Li+ takes about 0.6 water molecules per ion when intercalating Ti3C2Tx [53], thus keeping interlayer spacing open and allowing fast ionic transport. Li2SO4 electrolyte also showed the highest charge value of 226 C cm−3 at 10mV s−1, while LiClO4 and Na2SO4 showed up to 209 C cm−3 and 187 C cm−3, respectively. At a high scan rate of 1000mV s−1, the charge value of 165 C cm−3 was obtained in Li2SO4 and for LiClO4, and Na2SO4, charge values are found to be 96 C cm−3 and 131 C cm−3, respectively (Fig. 3d). The charge-discharge (GCD) (Fig. 3e) profiles were compared at a current density of 1 A g−1,
showing a good agreement with CV data. Moreover, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analysis was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 3f. All of the Nyquist plots of these three electrolytes exhibited nearly vertical slopes in the low frequency regime, indicating a close-to-ideal capacitive behavior. The high frequency regions in these three electrolytes showed similar equivalent series resistance (ESR) values. In addition, the long-term cycle stability was studied by repeating CV test for 10,000 times at 100mV s−1 (Fig. 3g). More than 98% of the capacitance was retained in all of three electrolytes (deaerated prior to the long cycling tests). From the above discussion, the 2D-Ti3C2Tx showed the maximum potential window of operation, higher capacitance, high rate capability, and long cycling life in 1M Li2SO4. So, 1M Li2SO4 was selected to work as the electrolyte for our high-voltage supercapacitor. The electrochemical performance of Ti3C2Tx free-standing film tested in 1M Li2SO4 electrolyte is shown in Fig. S3, in detail.
Since hydrogenation treatment after chlorination of nano-TiC minimizes the content of functional groups on the surface of nano-CDC, the surface tends to be hydrophobic in nature which forms a passive interface for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), enlarging the oxygen evolution overpotential [54]. To enhance the wettability of the nanoCDC electrodes, they were pre-cycled at high anodic potentials (at 0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl). The pore size of nano-CDC is around 0.8 nm, which can accommodate with the ionic size of SO42- (bare size of 0.29 nm and hydrated size of 0.53 nm) [55]. Based on our previous work [1], the
match of the pore size with the ionic size can contribute to the maximum capacity due to the ion desolvation process. As shown in Fig. S4a, it can be operated at a potential window of 0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Fig. 4a shows the CV curves of a nano-CDC free-standing film at different scan rates between 0 and 0.9 V, and typical rectangular profiles were observed even at a high scan rate of 1000mV s−1. Furthermore, its volumetric specific capacitance and Coulombic efficiency at different scan rates were calculated and shown in Fig. 4b. Notably, the nano-CDC films delivered a high volumetric specific capacitance of 143.2 F cm−3 at a scan rate of 10mV s−1, and retaining 65% at 1000mV s−1. Further, its gravimetric capacitance is calculated to be 77–50 F g−1. Moreover, its Coulombic efficiency reached 100% beyond the scan rate of 50mV s−1, in the chosen potential window. GCD curves of nano-CDC films (Fig. 4c) were recorded in the potential window of 0–0.9 V at different current densities ranging from 1 to 20 A g−1. The cycling stability of the nano-CDC films was evaluated by repeating the CV scans between 0 and 0.9 V at 100mV s−1 for 10,000 cycles, as shown in Fig. 4d. Notably, only 0.3% of the initial capacitance decayed after 10,000 charge-discharge cycles. It is in good agreement with previous studies where nano-CDC involves surface charge storage with excellent cycling stability [40]. Fig. S4b shows the Nyquist plots of the nano-CDC film before and after long-term cycling, which features a nearly vertical curve at low frequencies, indicating a close-to-ideal capacitive performance. The magnified high-frequency region reveals an equivalent series resistance (ESR) of 0.42Ω. However, the semicircle and Warburg region decreased after cycling due to greater access of electrolyte into nano-CDC. This is because the electrochemical cycling improved the wettability of the nano-CDC electrode, in reducing the charge transfer resistance and enhancing the electrolyte ions transport into carbon pores.
To demonstrate the high-voltage operation of the carbide-carbon asymmetric capacitor, we assembled 2D Ti3C2Tx film as a negative electrode and nano-CDC film as a positive electrode asymmetrically in 1M Li2SO4 aqueous electrolyte, which was tested in a Swagelok cell. Charge on both electrodes was balanced by controlling the mass loading using the following equation Q+m+ = Q-m- (Table S1, Supplementary
materials). Therefore, the ratio of mass balance was set to be 1:1.7 for Ti3C2Tx versus nano-CDC electrodes. The asymmetric device showed a 2 V stable operating voltage, which can be confirmed by its CVs with a progressive increment of the voltage window at a scan rate of 50mV s−1, as shown in Fig. 5a. This is the widest reported voltage window for MXene-based asymmetric supercapacitors in aqueous electrolyte (electrochemical performance of carbide-carbon capacitors is compared with that of other Ti3C2Tx MXene devices reported in the literature, Table S2). Further, CV scans are recorded over a scan rate range of 10–1000mV s−1, showing quasi-rectangular profiles indicating capacitive response of the device (Fig. 5b). The high rate capabilities can be attributed to the good electronic conductivity and the accessibility of electrode materials for electrolyte ions. The areal and volumetric capacitance of the asymmetric supercapacitor were calculated by integrating the discharge portions of the respective CVs with normalization based on total area and volume of the electrode materials (Fig. 5c). Notably, carbide-carbon device delivered an areal and volumetric capacitance of 51.2 mF cm−2 and 16.7 F cm−3, respectively at 10mV s−1. Furthermore, the device exhibited good rate performance, 41.3 mF cm−2 and 13.5 F cm−3 at 100mV s−1 and 29.4 mF cm−2 and 9.6 F cm−3 at 1000mV s−1 (71% rate retention). In addition, its gravimetric capacitance is varying between 19 and 11 F g−1. This is due to the rapid kinetics of electrolyte ions across the carbide and carbon electrodes. In Fig. S5a, the GCD curves of the asymmetric device are recorded at current densities from 1 to 20 A g−1, exhibiting the triangular profiles. Typical discharge times of devices are in the range of 36–3.6 s. To further evaluate the energy storage performance of the asymmetric capacitor, its energy density and power density were calculated from GCD profiles, as shown in Fig. S5b. The discharge times are in the range of 3.6 s, within these time scales, the energy and power densities of asymmetric device are either comparable or superior to that of carbon- and graphene-based asymmetric supercapacitors reported in the literature [56]. This can be attributed to the combined effects of pseudocapacitive MXene and highly microporous CDC electrodes. It can deliver a maximum energy density of 20.7 μWh cm−2 at a power density of 2.2mW cm−2 and an energy density of 10.2 μWh cm−2 at a
maximum power density of 26.7 mW cm−2. The volumetric performance of the asymmetric capacitor was estimated, which showed maximum energy density of 6.9Wh L−1 at a power density of 0.73 kW L−1, and maintained at 3Wh L−1 at a maximum power density of 11.5 kW L−1.
A leakage current test was also conducted by charging the asymmetric device to 2 V at 1mA and holding for 2 h (Fig. S5d). In this constant-voltage mode, the current through the stabilized device compensates the current loss by the capacitor itself, which can be recorded as the leakage current. For our carbide-carbon asymmetric capacitor, the current quickly stabilizes at 9 μA, which is essentially the leakage current through the device. Additionally, the constant current means that our asymmetric device is very stable under 2 V. After the hold test, we further measured the self-discharge as represented by the time course of the open-circuit voltage. During the test time, the voltage only decreased by 0.15 V before the voltage become stable. These results demonstrate that our device is stable under 2 V operating voltage and shows excellent low self-discharge characteristics, which is highly desirable for practical applications.
We have performed long-term cycling tests for our asymmetric capacitors, by repeating the CV test 10,000 times between 0 and 2 V at 100mV s−1. As shown in Fig. 5d, after 10,000 cycles, it still retained 99.6% of the initial capacitance, indicating an excellent cycle stability of the device. The Nyquist plot of the asymmetric device after the longterm cycling test is shown in Fig. S5c.
It is worth noting that a flexible device was assembled to demonstrate the application of Ti3C2Tx//CDC asymmetric device in flexible supercapacitor. The flexible device was sealed by a commercial Kapton type, by using freestanding Ti3C2Tx film as a negative electrode, nanoCDC film as a positive electrode, Celgard 3501 membrane as a separator and 1M Li2SO4 as electrolyte, whose digital picture was shown in the inset of Fig. 5d. To show its flexibility, a digital photograph of a bent device is shown in the inset of Fig. S6. The CVs in Fig. S6 demonstrate that only a subtle change of electrochemical performance occurred upon bending, indicating an excellent bending stability of the as prepared flexible asymmetric supercapacitor.
The CV tests of the single devices with in-parallel connected electrodes were conducted at 50mV s−1 between 0 and 2 V (Fig. 5e), in which the output current of the integrated module is almost twice that of a single device. The capacitance values of the single device and inparallel device were 63.8 mF cm−2 and 105.2 mF cm−2, respectively. Additionally, the in-series device was tested at 50mV s−1 between 0 and 4 V, from which a capacitance of 28.4 mF cm−2 was obtained. Such a good result indicates that the asymmetric capacitor is quite useful for practical applications, and its output current and voltage can be easily controlled by multi-electrode design and appropriate connection of electrodes. GCD results are matching to that of CV data (Fig. 5f). The electrochemical and mechanical stability during bending is also an important performance metric for the flexible and compact energy storage devices for wearables and other applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: We have demonstrated the design of 2 V aqueous carbide-carbon asymmetric supercapacitors by exploiting negative and positive operating potential windows of 2D titanium carbide (Ti3C2Tx MXene) and nano-CDC electrodes, respectively. The nature of precursors and processing parameters governed the functionality, structure and morphology of selected electrode materials. MXenes combine metallic conductivity with surface redox reactions across 2D gallery spaces, which are the key for high-rate pseudocapacitive energy storage while nano-CDC with a narrow micro pore size distribution within particles and mesoporous between particles is the key for high-rate electrical double layer charge storage. Such carbide-carbon asymmetric devices show high rate capabilities (71% retention from 10 to 1000mV s−1) in aqueous Li-electrolytes. The asymmetric device delivered a maximum areal energy density of 20.7 μWh cm−2 at a power density of 2.2 mW cm−2, and a maximum power density of 26.7 mW cm−2 with an energy density of 10.2 μWh cm−2. Furthermore, we have demonstrated the design of flexible bipolar multielectrode devices, showing promise for a variety of portable applications.

The authors acknowledge the Core Research Facilities (CRF) at Drexel University for providing access to characterization tools. J.L. thanks the support through the Special Excellent Ph.D. International Visit Program by Donghua University. Y.G. and X.M. also acknowledge the Thousand Talents program, China (WQ20152200273). We thank Dr. Xuehang Wang and Tyler Mathis (both, Drexel University) for helpful discussions.

sections.text: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.nanoen.2018.11.042.

metadata.abstractText: MXenes two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and nitrides are an emerging class of high rate pseudocapacitive materials due to their combination of fast surface redox reactions with metallic conductivity. The ability of MXenes to spontaneously intercalate aqueous cations, broadens the scope for developing metal-ion capacitors beyond the protic electrolytes. In this study, 2D titanium carbide (MXene) free-standing films are employed to evaluate the dependence of electrochemical performance in aqueous Li and Na-ion electrolytes. By contrast, high surface area porous nanoscale carbide derived carbon (nano-CDC) is employed as a surface electrosorbing electrode at anodic potentials. Both, 2D MXene and zero-dimensional (0D) nano-CDC, with contrasting charge storage mechanisms and complementary potential windows of operation, enable the construction of an aqueous Li-ion capacitor with a 2 V voltage window of operation. This asymmetric device shows high rate capability (71% retention from 10 to 1000mV s) and good cycling stability with 99.3% retention after 10,000 cycles. Furthermore, we demonstrate here the design of flexible bipolar carbide-carbon devices.
